abrogate: To repeal or do away with (a law, right, or formal agreement)
absolution: Formal release from guilt, obligation, or punishment
abstemious: Not self-indulgent, especially when eating and drinking
accede: To agree to a demand, request, or treaty
acerbity: Sourness or bitterness of taste, manner, or expression
acrimonious: Angry and bitter in feeling or manner
admonish: To warn or reprimand someone firmly
allegory: A story, poem, or picture that can be interpreted to reveal a hidden meaning, typically a moral or political one
altruism: Disinterested and selfless concern for the well-being of others
ambivalent: Having mixed feelings or contradictory ideas about something or someone
ameliorate: To make (something bad or unsatisfactory) better
anachronism: A thing belonging or appropriate to a period other than that in which it exists, especially a thing that is conspicuously old-fashioned
analgesic: An agent producing diminished sensation to pain
anathema: Something or someone that one vehemently dislikes
ancillary: Providing necessary support to the primary activities or operation of an organization, system, etc.
anomie: Lack of the usual social or ethical standards in an individual or group
antagonistic: Showing or feeling active opposition or hostility toward someone or something
antidiluvian: Of or belonging to the time before the biblical Flood; ridiculously old-fashioned
antipathy: A deep-seated feeling of dislike; aversion
antithesis: A person or thing that is in direct opposition to someone or something else
apathy: Lack of interest, enthusiasm, or concern
apocryphal: Of doubtful authenticity, although widely circulated as being true
apothegm: A concise saying or maxim; an aphorism
appease: To pacify or placate (someone) by acceding to their demands
apprehension: Anxiety or fear that something bad or unpleasant will happen
ascetic: Characterized by severe self-discipline and abstention from all forms of indulgence, typically for religious reasons
ascribe: To attribute something to (a cause, object, or person)
askance: With an attitude or look of suspicion or disapproval
assuage: To make (an unpleasant feeling) less intense
astringent: Causing the contraction of body tissues; sharp or severe in taste or manner
atavism: Reversion to an earlier type; recurrence of a primitive trait
atrophy: Waste away, typically due to the degeneration of cells, or become vestigial during evolution
auger: A tool used for boring holes
autochthonous: Indigenous rather than descended from migrants or colonists
aver: To state or assert to be the case
avuncular: Of or relating to an uncle
axiom: A statement or proposition which is regarded as being established, accepted, or self-evidently true
bane: A cause of great distress or annoyance
behoove: It is a duty or responsibility for (someone) to do something; it is incumbent on
belie: To contradict or show to be false
benign: Gentle and kindly; not harmful in effect
bête noire: A person or thing that one particularly dislikes
blandish: To coax (someone) with kind words or flattery
blithe: Showing a casual and cheerful indifference considered to be callous or improper
bogart: To use or consume selfishly, without sharing
bombastic: High-sounding but with little meaning; inflated
bowdlerize: To remove objectionable passages from a book or play
broach: To raise (a sensitive or difficult subject) for discussion
bromide: A trite or unoriginal remark; a cliché
brusque: Abrupt or offhand in speech or manner
burnish: To polish (metal or other material) by rubbing
cabal: A secret political clique or faction
cajole: To persuade someone to do something by sustained coaxing or flattery
calumny: The making of false and defamatory statements about someone in order to damage their reputation; slander
candor: The quality of being open and honest in expression; frankness
canon: A general law, rule, principle, or criterion by which something is judged
capitulate: To cease to resist an opponent or an unwelcome demand; surrender
capricious: Given to sudden and unaccountable changes of mood or behavior
captious: Apt to find fault or raise petty objections
carouse: To drink alcohol and enjoy oneself with others in a noisy, lively way
carte blanche: Complete freedom to act as one wishes
cataclysm: A large-scale and violent event in the natural world
cathartic: Providing psychological relief through the open expression of strong emotions
caustic: Able to burn or corrode organic tissue by chemical action; sarcastic in a scathing and bitter way
censure: Express severe disapproval of (someone or something), especially in a formal statement
chagrin: Distress or embarrassment at having failed or been humiliated
charlatan: A person falsely claiming to have a special knowledge or skill; a fraud
chicanery: The use of trickery to achieve a political, financial, or legal purpose
chimerical: Existing only as a product of unchecked imagination; fantastically visionary or improbable
circumlocution: The use of many words where fewer would do, especially in a deliberate attempt to be vague or evasive
coda: A concluding passage of a piece or movement, typically forming an independent section apart from the main structure
coerce: To persuade (an unwilling person) to do something by using force or threats
cognizant: Having knowledge or being aware of
commensurate: Corresponding in size or degree; in proportion
compendium: A collection of concise but detailed information about a particular subject
complaisant: Willing to please others; obliging; agreeable
compunction: A feeling of uneasiness or anxiety of the conscience caused by regret for doing wrong or causing pain; contrition; remorse
conflagration: An extensive fire which destroys a great deal of land or property
confluence: The act or process of merging
congenial: Pleasant or agreeable because suited to one's taste or inclination
conjecture: An opinion or conclusion formed on the basis of incomplete information
connive: To conspire to do something considered immoral, illegal, or harmful
connoisseur: An expert judge in matters of taste
connote: To imply or suggest (an idea or feeling) in addition to the literal or primary meaning
conscript: To enlist (someone) compulsorily, typically into the armed services
consign: To deliver (something) to a person's keeping
consternation: Feelings of anxiety or dismay, typically at something unexpected
construe: To interpret (a word or action) in a particular way
consummate: Showing great skill and flair; perfect
contravene: To violate the prohibition or order of (a law, treaty, or code of conduct)
contrite: Feeling or expressing remorse or penitence; affected by guilt
contumely: Insolent or insulting language or treatment
conundrum: A confusing and difficult problem or question
corollary: A proposition that follows (with little or no proof) from one already proved
corporeal: Relating to a person's body, especially as opposed to their spirit
corroborate: To confirm or give support to (a statement, theory, or finding)
coterie: A small group of people with shared interests or tastes
countenance: A person's face or facial expression
coup de grace: A final blow or shot given to kill a wounded person or animal
covet: To yearn to possess or have (something)
coy: Reluctant to give details, especially about something regarded as sensitive
credence: Belief in or acceptance of something as true
credulous: Having or showing too great a readiness to believe things
crepuscular: Of, relating to, or resembling twilight; active in the twilight
culminate: To reach a climax or point of highest development
cynosure: A person or thing that is the center of attention or admiration
dearth: A scarcity or lack of something
debacle: A sudden and ignominious failure; a fiasco
debasement: The act of reducing the quality or value of something
debunk: To expose the falseness or hollowness of (a myth, idea, or belief)
decimate: To kill, destroy, or remove a large proportion of
decorous: In keeping with good taste and propriety; polite and restrained
decrepit: Worn out or ruined because of age or neglect
defile: To spoil or desecrate (something sacred or revered)
demagogue: A political leader who seeks support by appealing to the desires and prejudices of ordinary people rather than by using rational argument
denizen: An inhabitant or occupant of a particular place
denouement: The final part of a play, movie, or narrative in which the strands of the plot are drawn together and matters are explained or resolved
depilate: To remove the hair from (a person's body)
derelict: In a very poor condition as a result of disuse and neglect
descry: To catch sight of (something distant or obscure)
desiccate: To remove the moisture from (something); to make dry
desultory: Lacking a plan, purpose, or enthusiasm
dichotomy: A division or contrast between two things that are or are represented as being opposed or entirely different
didactic: Intended to teach, particularly in having moral instruction as an ulterior motive
diffident: Modest or shy because of a lack of self-confidence
dilettante: A person who cultivates an area of interest, such as the arts, without real commitment or knowledge
disaffected: Dissatisfied with people in authority and no longer willing to support them
disburse: To pay out (money from a fund)
discomfit: To make (someone) feel uneasy or embarrassed
discrepancy: A lack of compatibility or similarity between two or more facts
disdain: The feeling that someone or something is unworthy of one's consideration or respect; contempt
disingenuous: Not candid or sincere, typically by pretending that one knows less about something than one really does
disparate: Essentially different in kind; not able to be compared
dispassionate: Not influenced by strong emotion, and so able to be rational and impartial
dispel: To make (a doubt, feeling, or belief) disappear
disquiet: A feeling of anxiety or worry
disseminate: To spread or disperse (something, especially information) widely
dissimulate: To conceal or disguise (one's thoughts, feelings, or character)
dissonance: Lack of harmony among musical notes; a tension or clash resulting from the combination of two disharmonious or unsuitable elements
dissuade: To persuade (someone) not to take a particular course of action
distend: To swell or cause to swell by pressure from inside
divisive: Tending to cause disagreement or hostility between people
dogged: Having or showing tenacity and grim persistence
dogmatic: Laying down principles as incontrovertibly true
dolorous: Feeling or expressing great sorrow or distress
dour: Relentlessly severe, stern, or gloomy in manner or appearance
droll: Curious or unusual in a way that provokes dry amusement
eclectic: Deriving ideas, style, or taste from a broad and diverse range of sources
edify: To instruct or improve (someone) morally or intellectually
efface: To erase (a mark) from a surface; to make oneself appear insignificant or inconspicuous
efficacious: Producing a desired or intended result
elegy: A poem of serious reflection, typically a lament for the dead
elicit: To evoke or draw out (a response, answer, or fact) from someone in reaction to one's own actions or questions
emaciated: Abnormally thin or weak, especially because of illness or a lack of food
embellish: To make (something) more attractive by the addition of decorative details or features
emollient: Having the quality of softening or soothing the skin; soothing, especially to the mind
empirical: Based on, concerned with, or verifiable by observation or experience rather than theory or pure logic
enervate: To cause (someone) to feel drained of energy or vitality; weaken
enfranchise: To give the right to vote to
ennui: A feeling of listlessness and dissatisfaction arising from a lack of occupation or excitement
enormity: The great or extreme scale, seriousness, or extent of something perceived as bad or morally wrong
ensconce: To establish or settle (someone) in a comfortable, safe, or secret place
ephemeral: Lasting for a very short time
epigram: A pithy saying or remark expressing an idea in a clever and amusing way
epiphany: A moment of sudden and great revelation or realization
epithet: An adjective or descriptive phrase expressing a quality characteristic of the person or thing mentioned
equanimity: Calmness and composure, especially in a difficult situation
equivocal: Open to more than one interpretation; ambiguous
erudite: Having or showing great knowledge or learning
eschew: To deliberately avoid using; abstain from
esoteric: Intended for or likely to be understood by only a small number of people with a specialized knowledge or interest
espouse: To adopt or support (a cause, belief, or way of life)
euphemism: A mild or indirect word or expression substituted for one considered to be too harsh or blunt when referring to something unpleasant or embarrassing
euphony: The quality of being pleasing to the ear through a harmonious combination of words
exacerbate: To make (a problem, bad situation, or negative feeling) worse
exculpate: To clear from alleged fault or guilt
exhort: To strongly encourage or urge (someone) to do something
exonerate: To officially absolve someone from blame for a fault or wrongdoing
expunge: To erase or remove completely (something unwanted or unpleasant)
extirpate: To root out and destroy completely
extraneous: Irrelevant or unrelated to the subject being dealt with
extricate: To free (someone or something) from a constraint or difficulty
exult: To feel or show triumphant elation or jubilation
facetious: Treating serious issues with deliberately inappropriate humor; flippant
facile: Appearing to be comprehensive or thorough but lacking in depth
feckless: Lacking initiative or strength of character; irresponsible
fecund: Producing or capable of producing an abundance of offspring or new growth; fertile
felicitous: Well chosen or suited to the circumstances; pleasing and fortunate
feral: In a wild state, especially after escape from captivity or domestication
fervent: Having or displaying a passionate intensity
fidelity: Faithfulness to a person, cause, or belief, demonstrated by continuing loyalty and support
figurative: Departing from a literal use of words; metaphorical
filibuster: An action such as a prolonged speech that obstructs progress in a legislative assembly while not technically contravening the required procedures
fissure: A long, narrow opening or line of breakage made by cracking or splitting, especially in rock or earth
flaccid: Soft and hanging loosely or limply; lacking force or effectiveness
flagellate: To flog (someone) or oneself, especially as a religious discipline
flout: To openly disregard (a rule, law, or convention)
foil: To prevent (something considered wrong or undesirable) from succeeding
foment: To instigate or stir up (an undesirable or violent sentiment or course of action)
forlorn: Pitifully sad and abandoned or lonely
formidable: Inspiring fear or respect through being impressively large, powerful, intense, or capable
fortuitous: Happening by chance rather than intention
frieze: A broad horizontal band of sculpted or painted decoration, especially on a wall near the ceiling
frivolous: Not having any serious purpose or value
furlough: Leave of absence, especially that granted to a member of the services or a seaman
furtive: Attempting to avoid notice or attention, typically because of guilt or a belief that discovery would lead to trouble; secretive
gainsay: To deny or contradict (a fact or statement)
gallivant: To go around from place to place enjoying oneself
garner: To gather or collect (something, especially information or approval)
garrulous: Excessively talkative, especially on trivial matters
genre: A category of artistic composition, as in music or literature, characterized by similarities in form, style, or subject matter
germane: Relevant to a subject under consideration
gist: The substance or essence of a speech or text
glib: Fluent and voluble but insincere and shallow
gnomic: Expressed in or of the nature of short, pithy maxims or aphorisms
gourmand: A person who enjoys eating and often eats too much
grandiloquent: Pompous or extravagant in language, style, or manner, especially in a way that is intended to impress
gratuitous: Uncalled for; lacking good reason; unwarranted
grievous: Causing severe pain, suffering, or sorrow
grouse: To complain or grumble about something trivial
hackneyed: Lacking significance through having been overused; unoriginal and trite
harbinger: A person or thing that announces or signals the approach of another
harridan: A strict, bossy, or belligerent old woman
hegemony: Leadership or dominance, especially by one country or social group over others
heterodox: Not conforming with accepted or orthodox standards or beliefs
histrionic: Overly theatrical or melodramatic in character or style
hoary: Having gray or white hair; ancient
hone: To sharpen (a blade); to refine or perfect (something)
ignominious: Deserving or causing public disgrace or shame
imbibe: To drink (alcohol); to absorb or assimilate (ideas or knowledge)
imperious: Assuming power or authority without justification; arrogant and domineering
impetuous: Acting or done quickly and without thought or care
impinge: To have an effect or impact, especially a negative one
implacable: Unable to be appeased or placated
importune: To harass (someone) persistently for or to do something
impugn: To dispute the truth, validity, or honesty of (a statement or motive); call into question
inadvertent: Not resulting from or achieved through deliberate planning
inchoate: Just begun and so not fully formed or developed; rudimentary
incipient: In an initial stage; beginning to happen or develop
incontrovertible: Not able to be denied or disputed
incorrigible: Not able to be corrected, improved, or reformed
incumbent: Necessary for (someone) as a duty or responsibility
indigenous: Originating or occurring naturally in a particular place; native
indolent: Wanting to avoid activity or exertion; lazy
ineffable: Too great or extreme to be expressed or described in words
ineluctable: Unable to be avoided or escaped; inescapable
inept: Having or showing no skill; clumsy
inimical: Tending to obstruct or harm; unfriendly or hostile
insidious: Proceeding in a gradual, subtle way, but with harmful effects
insinuate: To suggest or hint (something bad or reprehensible) in an indirect and unpleasant way
insouciant: Showing a casual lack of concern; indifferent
instigate: To bring about or initiate (an action or event)
interlocutor: A person who takes part in a dialogue or conversation
internecine: Destructive to both sides in a conflict
interpolated: Inserted (something of a different nature) into something else
intransigent: Unwilling or refusing to change one's views or to agree about something
inured: Accustomed to something, especially something unpleasant
invective: Insulting, abusive, or highly critical language
inveigh: To speak or write about (something) with great hostility
inveigle: To persuade (someone) to do something by means of deception or flattery
invidious: Likely to arouse resentment or anger in others, especially by being unfair or unjust
irascible: Having or showing a tendency to be easily angered
irreverent: Showing a lack of respect for people or things that are generally taken seriously
jettison: To throw or drop (something) from an aircraft or ship; to abandon or discard (someone or something that is no longer wanted)
jingoism: Extreme patriotism, especially in the form of aggressive or warlike foreign policy
jubilant: Feeling or expressing great happiness and triumph
juxtapose: To place or deal with close together for contrasting effect
lament: A passionate expression of grief or sorrow
languid: Having a disinclination for physical exertion or effort; slow and relaxed
largess: Generosity in bestowing money or gifts upon others
lassitude: A state of physical or mental weariness; lack of energy
legerdemain: Skillful use of one's hands when performing tricks
lethargy: A state of tiredness, weariness, or lack of energy
levity: Humor or frivolity, especially the treatment of a serious matter with humor or in a manner lacking due respect
lexicon: The vocabulary of a person, language, or branch of knowledge
libertine: A person, especially a man, who behaves without moral principles or a sense of responsibility, especially in sexual matters
licentious: Promiscuous and unprincipled in sexual matters
litany: A tedious or repetitive series or recital
locus: A particular position, point, or place
loquacious: Tending to talk a great deal; talkative
lugubrious: Looking or sounding sad and dismal
macabre: Disturbing and horrifying because of involvement with or depiction of death and injury
machination: A scheming or crafty action or artful design intended to accomplish some (usually evil) end
maelstrom: A powerful whirlpool in the sea or a river; a situation or state of confused movement or violent turmoil
magnanimous: Generous or forgiving, especially toward a rival or less powerful person
malediction: A magical word or phrase uttered with the intention of bringing about evil or destruction; a curse
malefactor: A person who commits a crime or other wrong
malfeasance: Wrongdoing, especially by a public official
malign: Evil in nature or effect; malevolent
malinger: To exaggerate or feign illness in order to escape duty or work
malleable: Able to be hammered or pressed permanently out of shape without breaking or cracking; easily influenced
mandate: An official order or commission to do something
maudlin: Self-pityingly or tearfully sentimental, often through drunkenness
mawkish: Sentimental in an exaggerated or false way
melancholy: A feeling of pensive sadness, typically with no obvious cause
mellifluous: Sweet or musical; pleasant to hear
mercenary: A professional soldier hired to serve in a foreign army
mercurial: Subject to sudden or unpredictable changes of mood or mind
meticulous: Showing great attention to detail; very careful and precise
mien: A person's look or manner, especially indicating their character or mood
misanthrope: A person who dislikes humankind and avoids human society
mitigate: To make less severe, serious, or painful
modicum: A small quantity of a particular thing, especially something desirable or valuable
mollify: To appease the anger or anxiety of (someone)
moribund: At the point of death; in terminal decline
multifarious: Having many different parts or elements; numerous and varied
munificent: Larger or more generous than is usual or necessary
myopic: Nearsighted; lacking imagination, foresight, or intellectual insight
nadir: The lowest point in the fortunes of a person or organization
nascent: Just coming into existence and beginning to display signs of future potential
neophyte: A person who is new to a subject, skill, or belief
nexus: A connection or series of connections linking two or more things
nonchalant: Feeling or appearing casually calm and relaxed; not displaying anxiety, interest, or enthusiasm
nonplussed: Surprised and confused so much that they are unsure how to react
obdurate: Stubbornly refusing to change one's opinion or course of action
obfuscate: To make obscure, unclear, or unintelligible
obloquy: Strong public criticism or verbal abuse
obsequious: Obedient or attentive to an excessive or servile degree
occlude: To stop, close up, or obstruct (an opening, orifice, or passage)
officious: Asserting authority or power in a domineering way, especially with regard to trivial matters
ominous: Giving the worrying impression that something bad is going to happen; threateningly inauspicious
onerous: Involving an amount of effort and difficulty that is oppressively burdensome
opaque: Not transparent or translucent; impossible to see through
opine: To hold and state as one's opinion
opulent: Ostentatiously rich and luxurious or lavish
oscillate: To move or swing back and forth at a regular speed
ostensible: Stated or appearing to be true, but not necessarily so
ostracize: To exclude (someone) from a society or group
paean: A song of praise or triumph
palatable: Pleasant to taste; acceptable or satisfactory
palliate: To make (a disease or its symptoms) less severe or unpleasant without removing the cause; to disguise the seriousness or gravity of (an offense or mistake)
palpable: Able to be touched or felt
panacea: A solution or remedy for all difficulties or diseases
panegyric: A public speech or published text in praise of someone or something
paradigm: A typical example or pattern of something; a model
paragon: A person or thing regarded as a perfect example of a particular quality
parlance: A particular way of speaking or using words, especially one common to those with a particular profession or interest
parley: A conference between opposing sides in a dispute, especially a discussion of terms for an armistice
parsimonious: Unwilling to spend money or use resources; stingy or frugal
partisan: A strong supporter of a party, cause, or person
paucity: The presence of something only in small or insufficient quantities or amounts; scarcity
pecuniary: Relating to or consisting of money
pedantic: Excessively concerned with minor details or rules; overscrupulous
penchant: A strong or habitual liking for something or tendency to do something
penury: The state of being very poor; destitution
percipient: Having a good understanding of things; perceptive
perdition: A state of eternal punishment and damnation into which a sinful and unpenitent person passes after death
peremptory: Insisting on immediate attention or obedience, especially in a brusquely imperious way
perfunctory: Carried out with a minimum of effort or reflection
peripatetic: Traveling from place to place, especially working or making excursions on foot
perjury: The offense of willfully telling an untruth in a court of law after taking an oath or affirmation
pernicious: Having a harmful effect, especially in a gradual or subtle way
perspicacious: Having a ready insight into and understanding of things
peruse: To read (something), typically in a thorough or careful way
phlegmatic: Having an unemotional and stolidly calm disposition
picaresque: Relating to an episodic style of fiction dealing with the adventures of a rough and dishonest but appealing hero
placate: To make (someone) less angry or hostile
platitude: A remark or statement, especially one with a moral content, that has been used too often to be interesting or thoughtful
plethora: A large or excessive amount of something
polemic: A strong verbal or written attack on someone or something
portend: To be a sign or warning that (something momentous or calamitous) is likely to happen
potentate: A monarch or ruler, especially an autocratic one
precarious: Not securely held or in position; dangerously likely to fall or collapse
precipitous: Dangerously high or steep; done with very great haste and without due consideration
preclude: To prevent from happening; make impossible
precocious: Having developed certain abilities or proclivities at an earlier age than usual
precursor: A person or thing that comes before another of the same kind; a forerunner
predilection: A preference or special liking for something; a bias in favor of something
premonition: A strong feeling that something is about to happen, especially something unpleasant
preponderance: The quality or fact of being greater in number, quantity, or importance
prescient: Having or showing knowledge of events before they take place
prescience: The fact of knowing something before it takes place; foreknowledge
prevaricate: To speak or act in an evasive way
primordial: Existing at or from the beginning of time; ancient
probity: The quality of having strong moral principles; honesty and decency
proclivity: A tendency to choose or do something regularly; an inclination or predisposition toward a particular thing
prodigal: Spending money or resources freely and recklessly; wastefully extravagant
prodigious: Remarkably or impressively great in extent, size, or degree
profligate: Recklessly extravagant or wasteful in the use of resources
prognosticate: To foretell or prophesy (an event in the future)
proliferate: To increase rapidly in numbers; multiply
promulgate: To promote or make widely known (an idea or cause)
propensity: An inclination or natural tendency to behave in a particular way
propitious: Giving or indicating a good chance of success; favorable
prosaic: Having the style or diction of prose; lacking imaginativeness or originality
protagonist: The leading character or one of the major characters in a drama, movie, novel, or other fictional text
protean: Able to change frequently or easily
provident: Making or indicating timely preparation for the future; frugal
provisional: Arranged or existing for the present, possibly to be changed later
provocation: Action or speech that makes someone annoyed or angry, especially deliberately
puerile: Of or characteristic of a child; childishly silly and trivial
pugnacious: Eager or quick to argue, quarrel, or fight
punctilious: Showing great attention to detail or correct behavior
pundit: An expert in a particular subject or field who is frequently called upon to give opinions about it to the public
pungent: Having a sharply strong taste or smell
quagmire: A soft boggy area of land that gives way underfoot; an awkward, complex, or hazardous situation
quandary: A state of perplexity or uncertainty over what to do in a difficult situation
querulous: Complaining in a petulant or whining manner
quiescent: In a state or period of inactivity or dormancy
quintessence: The most perfect or typical example of a quality or class
quotidian: Of or occurring every day; daily
rancor: Bitterness or resentfulness, especially when long-standing
rapport: A close and harmonious relationship in which the people or groups concerned understand each other's feelings or ideas and communicate well
rarefy: To make or become more rare or less dense
ratiocinate: To form judgments by a process of reasoning
recalcitrant: Having an obstinately uncooperative attitude toward authority or discipline
recant: To say that one no longer holds an opinion or belief, especially one considered heretical
recidivism: The tendency of a convicted criminal to reoffend
recondite: Dealing with a very profound, difficult, or abstruse subject
redress: Remedy or compensation for a wrong or grievance
redundant: Not or no longer needed or useful; superfluous
refute: To prove (a statement or theory) to be wrong or false; disprove
relegate: To consign or dismiss to a lower, less important rank or position
renege: To go back on a promise, undertaking, or contract
repartee: Conversation or replies that are quick and witty
reprobate: An unprincipled person (often used humorously or affectionately)
repudiate: To refuse to accept or be associated with
requisite: Made necessary by particular circumstances or regulations
resilient: Able to spring back into shape after bending, stretching, or being compressed; able to recoil or recover quickly from difficult conditions
restive: Unable to keep still or silent and becoming increasingly difficult to control, especially because of impatience, dissatisfaction, or boredom
reticent: Not revealing one's thoughts or feelings readily
reverent: Feeling or showing deep and solemn respect
ribald: Referring to sexual matters in an amusingly rude or irreverent way
rife: Widespread, especially of something undesirable or harmful
rococo: Of or characterized by an elaborately ornamental late baroque style of decoration prevalent in 18th-century Continental Europe, with asymmetrical patterns involving scrolled motifs, foliage, and shellwork
roil: To make (a liquid) turbid or muddy by stirring up the sediment; to disturb or disquiet (someone)
rudimentary: Involving or limited to basic principles
rueful: Expressing sorrow or regret, especially when in a slightly humorous way
sacrosanct: Regarded as too important or valuable to be interfered with
sagacious: Having or showing keen mental discernment and good judgment; wise or shrewd
sanctimonious: Making a show of being morally superior to other people
sanguine: Optimistic or positive, especially in an apparently difficult situation
satiate: To satisfy (a desire or an appetite) to the full
savoir faire: The ability to act appropriately in social situations
scintillating: Sparkling or shining brightly; brilliantly clever or skillful
scion: A descendant of a notable family
scurrilous: Making or spreading scandalous claims about someone with the intention of damaging their reputation
sebaceous: Relating to or secreting fat or sebum
sentient: Able to perceive or feel things
sepulchral: Relating to a tomb or interment; gloomy and dismal
serendipity: The occurrence and development of events by chance in a happy or beneficial way
shibboleth: A custom, principle, or belief distinguishing a particular class or group of people, especially a long-standing one regarded as outmoded or no longer important
simian: Relating to or resembling apes or monkeys
sinecure: A position requiring little or no work but giving the holder status or financial benefit
skulduggery: Underhand, unscrupulous, or dishonest behavior or activities
solicitous: Characterized by or showing interest or concern
sonorous: Imposingly deep and full of sound
sophistry: The use of specious reasoning, especially with the intention of deceiving
soporific: Tending to induce drowsiness or sleep
sporadic: Occurring at irregular intervals or only in a few places; scattered or isolated
spurious: Not being what it purports to be; false or fake
squalid: Extremely dirty and unpleasant, especially as a result of poverty or neglect
stanch: To stop or restrict (a flow of blood from a wound)
stentorian: Of a person's voice) loud and powerful
stigma: A mark of disgrace associated with a particular circumstance, quality, or person
stipend: A fixed regular sum paid as a salary or allowance
stolid: Calm, dependable, and showing little emotion or animation
stratagem: A plan or scheme, especially one used to outwit an opponent or achieve an end
stymie: To prevent or hinder the progress of
subjugate: To bring under domination or control, especially by conquest
sublime: Of such excellence, grandeur, or beauty as to inspire great admiration or awe
suborn: To bribe or otherwise induce (someone) to commit an unlawful act such as perjury
subterfuge: Deceit used in order to achieve one's goal
succor: Assistance and support in times of hardship and distress
supercilious: Behaving or looking as though one thinks one is superior to others
superfluous: Unnecessary, especially through being more than enough
supersede: To take the place of (a person or thing previously in authority or use); supplant
surreptitious: Kept secret, especially because it would not be approved of
sycophant: A person who acts obsequiously toward someone important in order to gain advantage
synaptic: Relating to a synapse or synapses
tacit: Understood or implied without being stated
taciturn: Reserved or uncommunicative in speech; saying little
talisman: An object, typically an inscribed ring or stone, that is thought to have magic powers and to bring good luck
tangential: Diverging from a previous course or line; erratic
tapestry: A piece of thick textile fabric with pictures or designs formed by weaving colored weft threads or by embroidering on canvas, used as a wall hanging or furniture covering
tardiness: The quality or fact of being late; slowness
tatterdemalion: A person in ragged clothes; ragged or disreputable in appearance
tautology: The saying of the same thing twice in different words, generally considered to be a fault of style (e.g., 'they arrived one after the other in succession')
temperance: Abstinence from alcoholic drink; moderation or self-restraint
tendentious: Expressing or favoring a particular cause or point of view, especially a controversial one
tergiversate: To make conflicting or evasive statements; equivocate
timorous: Showing or suffering from nervousness, fear, or a lack of confidence
tirade: A long, angry speech of criticism or accusation
tortuous: Full of twists and turns; excessively lengthy and complex
transgress: To infringe or go beyond the bounds of (a moral principle or other established standard of behavior)
travesty: A false, absurd, or distorted representation of something
trenchant: Vigorous or incisive in expression or style
trepidation: A feeling of fear or agitation about something that may happen
truculent: Eager or quick to argue or fight; aggressively defiant
truncate: To shorten (something) by cutting off the top or the end
undulate: To move with a smooth wave-like motion
unimpeachable: Not able to be doubted, questioned, or criticized; entirely trustworthy
unpropitious: Indicating a poor chance of success; unfavorable
untenable: Not able to be maintained or defended against attack or objection
usurp: To take (a position of power or importance) illegally or by force
uxorious: Having or showing an excessive fondness for one's wife
vacillate: To alternate or waver between different opinions or actions; be indecisive
vacuous: Having or showing a lack of thought or intelligence; mindless
vagary: An unexpected and inexplicable change in a situation or in someone's behavior
valiant: Possessing or showing courage or determination
vehement: Showing strong feeling; forceful, passionate, or intense
vendetta: A prolonged bitter quarrel with or campaign against someone
venerate: To regard with great respect; revere
verbose: Using or expressed in more words than are needed
verdant: Green with grass or other rich vegetation
verisimilitude: The appearance of being true or real
veritable: Used as an intensifier, often to qualify a metaphor
vicarious: Experienced in the imagination through the feelings or actions of another person
vicissitude: A change of circumstances or fortune, typically one that is unwelcome or unpleasant
vilify: To speak or write about in an abusively disparaging manner
vindicate: To clear (someone) of blame or suspicion; to show or prove to be right, reasonable, or justified
vindictive: Having or showing a strong or unreasoning desire for revenge
virile: Having or characterized by strength, energy, and a strong sex drive; masculine
virulent: Extremely severe or harmful in its effects
visceral: Relating to deep inward feelings rather than to the intellect
vitriolic: Full of bitter verbal abuse or malice
volition: The faculty or power of using one's will
voluble: Speaking or spoken incessantly and fluently
wan: Pale and giving the impression of illness or exhaustion
whet: To sharpen the blade of (a tool or weapon); to excite or stimulate (someone's desire, interest, or appetite)
whimsical: Playfully quaint or fanciful, especially in an appealing and amusing way
wily: Skilled at gaining an advantage, especially deceitfully
winsome: Attractive or appealing in a fresh, innocent way
woeful: Of or characterized by sorrow or misery
wry: Using or expressing dry, especially mocking, humor
xenophobia: Dislike of or prejudice against people from other countries
yarn: A long or rambling story, especially one that is untrue or implausible
yoke: A wooden crosspiece that is fastened over the necks of two animals and attached to the plow or cart that they are to pull; a burden or something that oppresses
zealot: A person who is fanatical and uncompromising in pursuit of their religious, political, or other ideals
zenith: The time at which something is most powerful or successful
